news_header: Samuel Weidenhofer, who faced mental health struggles, turned to social media to spread positivity and kindness, gaining millions of followers. Kindness content creators are on the rise, but their methods face criticism for being performative.
news_original_title: Why do kindness influencers get criticised?
news_text: Samuel Weidenhofer struggled with mental health issues after a family tragedy and bullying. At 17, he began using social media to spread positivity through acts of kindness, gaining a large following. Other kindness influencers have emerged, sharing similar content that often involves surprising strangers with gifts. While these videos attract millions of views and promote positivity, they also face criticism for being performative and potentially exploitative. Critics argue that the focus on vulnerable individuals can be troubling, and there are concerns about the management of large sums of money given to those in need. Influencers defend their methods, claiming they can help more people through their platforms.
